prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity: line emission
We have downloaded the publicly available MOPRA spectra of Russeil et al. (2010), and used their peak fluxes as predictions for the sensitivity calculations. The MOPRA show typical lines having peak T_MB=6 K in a 33" beam with 1 km/s line widths. The MOPRA beam projects to 0.3 pc at the 1.9 kpc distance of NGC 6357 and we expect core structures with sizes of <0.1 pc, so the filling fraction could be <10%, implying brightness temperatures consistent with the excitation temperatures derived for some of the sources (T_ex > 30 K). Comparing to well-resolved emission in the CLASSy survey of nearby cores, the typical maximum emission in an HCN spectrum is T_mb = 8 K. These arguments imply that detecting brightness temperatures T>8 K on small scales, where the synthesized beam is matched to the structure, which is equivalent to 250 mJy in the ALMA beam. The high resolution is driven by the desire to detect small scale structures within cores and filaments, which should be brighter than this. Since we will recover all spatial scales, the data can be smoothed to pick up lower surface brightness emission. We select a sensitivity of 50 mJy to best balance needed sensitivity (>3 sigma detections for all clump-like structures) with observing time (18 s per pointing for this sensitivity) to allow for a large mosaic in which all clumps should be detected. Note that we will detect the 13C isotopologues precisely where we need them: where the emission the 12C isotopologue becomes optically thick.
Sensitivity: continuum
Beuther et al. (2010) derived peak intensities of 13-55 mJy/beam at 3.4 mm with ATCA in the cores associated with the source NGC 6334 I(N). Since our synthesized beam is of comparable size, we take the average (34 mJy) as our expected peak continuum flux. With the above line sensitivity, we achieve a sensitivity of 0.21 mJy (1 sigma) and a signal-to-noise > 150. This should be more than sufficient to trace the extended dust structure within this region. Continuum data can be combined with the continuum observations taken in the N2H+/HNC spectral setup for increased sensitivity, if needed.

This setup obtains the dense gas tracers HCN and HCO+ and their optically thin isotopologues H13CN and H13CO+, all in the J=1-0 transition. The setup also provides for one continuum band observed in FDM to detect other high density tracers that may be present within the band. Accurate estimation of continuum levels also requires resolving contaminating species.
Linewidths of clumps in this region are measured to be 1-2 km/s, but there are likely multiple components along the line of sight in some cases (Russeil et al. 2010). Furthermore, HCN and HCO+ are excellent tracers of infall motions, but high resolution is needed to separate blue- and red-shifted components to detect infall and measure its velocity. A resolution of 0.12 km/s (after Hanning smoothing) for HCN and HCO+ is needed to separate velocity and spatially separated components, accurately model hyperfine structure, and trace velocity dispersion down to near thermal values (0.13 km/s FWHM for HCN at 10 K). A slightly coarser resolution of 0.24 km/s for the optically thin isotopologues should be sufficient to still detect them, and the higher sensitivity will aid in detecting these weaker lines. These lines are important in deriving systemic velocities for cores and validating the kinematic signatures of the optically thick lines.

This setup obtains the dense gas tracers HCN and HCO+ and their optically thin isotopologues H13CN and H13CO+, all in the J=1-0 transition. The setup also provides for one continuum band. The mosaic covers a ~10 pc2 region extending along a dense filament that is furthermore mostly dark at mid-infrared wavelengths, southeast of the HII region G353.1+0.6. It includes seven massive clumps.
Our science goals require extremely high spatial dynamic range. In particular, obtaining reliable maps of the 10 square pc mosaic region, distinguishing between star formation modes, understanding the scales on which each operates, and making accurate predictions relevant to extragalactic all necessitate having high fidelity at all spatial scales. Our resolution of 2 arcsec (0.02 pc) allows us to probe the thousand-AU scales of individual cores, while the use of the ACA recovers the extended structure clearly seen in previous studies of NGC 6357, achieving a spatial dynamic range of ~500. As measured through simulations by Offner et al. (2011), the lack of ACA coverage can lead to misleading results regarding the substructure of star-forming cores, so we stress the importance of including these short-spacing and total power observations.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The majority of our observational knowledge of the star formation process is derived from studies of nearby low-mass regions, yet the majority of the energy and momentum involved in star formation is injected by massive stars. This asymmetry in our understanding is a result of the relative inaccessibility of massive star-forming regions to high-spatial resolution observations. Further progress in this area requires investigation into both the substructure of star-forming clouds (at the scales of prestellar cores) and the environmental medium in which these cores form and evolve. We propose to undertake a comprehensive investigation of the dense molecular ISM in the massive star-forming region NGC 6357 with ALMA. We will map three regions in varying environmental conditions in 3.3 mm continuum and the dense gas tracers HCN, HCO+, N2H+, and several of their isotopologues at 0.1 km/s resolution. We will investigate the interconnected structure of the ISM from ~5000 AU scales up to our mosaic size of ~5 pc, model our results to attempt to discriminate between various modes of star formation, and extrapolate to other galaxies.
